Glennifer Falls drops in two visible long falls â€“ the second of these coursing down a narrow, vertical fissure in the face of the mountain. The total visible drop is easily more than 100m, but above this the river steps back in three earlier falls, one of these being an impressive 60m.

Disclaimer: This canyon is a dangerous undertaking. The catchment is 18 square km's in a high rainfall area which floods regularly. Only highly experienced canyoners with experience in highly technical high flow canyoning should attempt. If your experience is predominantly Blue Mountains canyoning you should stay away.

Background

first decent in 1994

Mitchell Stewart - March 29 2019

Ryan Hunter, Alex O'Connor Mason and myself made a full descent of Gleniffer Falls canyon on Wednesday the 20th of February, 2019. This canyon is intimidating and steep and features some of the best waterfall abseils in Australia. This trip is one of the top three outdoor experiences I've ever had in Australia. The slot in the lower part of the falls terrifying yet spectacular!! Disclaimer- This canyon is a dangerous undertaking. The catchment is 18 square km's in a high rainfall area which floods regularly. We saw almost no evidence of previous descents, indicating that the waterway has the potential to pick up large amounts of rock and log debris destroying any anchor systems put in place. This was evident by the large logs that were seen high up on a ledge in the first large pool system. Our party has been canyoning in many countries around the world and we are very experienced in high flow canyons. We recognised many signs of what this canyon is capable of in the wrong (wet...) conditions. It is not recommended to enter this canyon before, during, or after rain and without the ability to replace bolted anchors (hammer drill and bolting kit is required). After the 3rd abseil... you are totally committed to the descent, so be aware that there are no escape routes and you must be confident in your experience and ability to commit to a full descent. 80m ropes are ESSENTIAL and we recommend taking three ropes... be WELL prepared for an overnight stay with space blankets and food. Btw utmost respect to Dicky Baker, Andy Robb, Brian Cork, and Dan for their efforts involved with this tremendous canyon. Following are a few photos of our experience, with more details and a canyon topo to come. Photos taken by Ryan Mad Dog Hunter!!!!
